title: We've Learnt Nothing: 3.5 Lakh Trees To Be Cut In Jharkhand's Palamau Tiger Reserve, For A Dam

We've Learnt Nothing: 3.5 Lakh Trees To Be Cut In Jharkhand's Palamau Tiger Reserve, For A Dam

We've Learnt Nothing: 3.5 Lakh Trees To Be Cut In Jharkhand's Palamau Tiger Reserve, For A Dam

Wildlife experts have raised an alarm at the decision of the water department to cut over 3.44 lakh trees in Jharkhand’s Palamau Tiger Reserve (PTR) for Mandal dam, also known as the North Koel project.

As per the All India Tiger Estimation (AITE) results that were declared about two months ago, no tiger was reportedly recorded in this particular reserve.

The construction of the reservoir threatens the existence of 3,44,644 trees.

Reportedly, the permission to fell trees has already been granted to the water resource department.

Travel India

Rs 461 crore has been deposited to the forest department for this purpose, the water resource department has claimed. Chief engineer of water resource department, Daltonganj, Mukesh Kumar reportedly said, “We have sought NOC from the forest department to begin several works including on forest land. Centre’s agency WAPCOS Pvt limited will execute the tree felling work.”

Two years ago the union environment ministry approved the diversion of 1,000 hectares of forest land for the revival of Mandal Dam, which is going to involve felling of lakhs of trees in the ‘tigerless’ reserve.

The move is being opposed by the former state chief wildlife warden, Pradeep Kumar who says the felling of trees in such a large number would effect the ecosystem of the tiger reserve.

“The reserve has already suffered significant damage due to expansion of the state’s road and railway network. Now, felling of trees will add further damaged to the biodiversity,” he reportedly said.
